definitions: crowd or press together in large numbers, filling a space with many people
examples: Tourists throng the beaches during summer vacation season
Fans thronged outside the stadium before the concert

definitions: control the flow of fuel or power to an engine to regulate its speed
attack or kill someone by choking or strangling them by compressing the throat
examples: The pilot throttled back the engines for landing approach
Race car drivers must throttle carefully through tight corners
The attacker tried to throttle his victim with bare hands
Anger nearly throttled him as he struggled to speak

definitions: push something or someone suddenly or violently in a specified direction with force
make a sudden forward movement with a part of the body or weapon
examples: She thrust the letter into his hands and walked away
The rocket engines thrust the spacecraft into orbit
The fencer thrust his sword at his opponent's chest
He thrust his jaw forward in defiance

definitions: hit or strike heavily with the fist or a blunt object making a dull sound
beat or pulsate strongly and rapidly, especially the heart from exertion or emotion
examples: He thumped his fist on the table in frustration
The children thumped down the stairs noisily
Her heart thumped wildly as she waited for results
The bass drum thumped throughout the entire song

definitions: produce a loud rumbling or crashing noise like the sound following lightning
speak loudly and forcefully in an angry or dramatic way
examples: The waterfall thunders constantly in the canyon below
Heavy trucks thunder past our house all day long
The coach thundered instructions from the sidelines
The judge thundered his verdict to the silent courtroom

definitions: prevent someone from accomplishing something by opposing them or creating obstacles to their plans
examples: Bad weather thwarted our plans for a picnic
Security measures thwarted the attempted robbery at the bank

definitions: make a regular short sharp sound like a clock or watch mechanism
mark an item on a list with a checkmark to show completion or selection
examples: The old grandfather clock ticks loudly in the hallway
The bomb ticked ominously as time ran out
Please tick the boxes that apply to your situation
She ticked off each item on her grocery list

definitions: touch someone lightly in a way that causes laughter or twitching movements
appeal to or amuse someone in a way that gives pleasure or satisfaction
examples: The baby giggles when you tickle her feet
Feathers tickle your nose and make you sneeze
That joke really tickled my funny bone
The idea of surprising him tickled her imagination

definitions: arrange things neatly and in order by putting them in their proper places
examples: Please tidy your room before guests arrive tonight
She tidies the office every evening before leaving

definitions: make something tighter by turning, pulling, or stretching it to reduce slack
make rules, controls, or procedures stricter or more rigorous than before
examples: Tighten the screws to secure the shelf properly
She tightened her grip on the steering wheel
The government plans to tighten immigration laws this year
Banks tightened lending requirements after the financial crisis

definitions: cover a surface with tiles arranged in a pattern for decoration or protection
examples: They decided to tile the bathroom floor with marble
Workers tiled the kitchen backsplash with colorful ceramic pieces

definitions: move or cause to move into a sloping position at an angle
engage in a joust or similar contest on horseback with lances
examples: The earthquake tilted the picture frames on the wall
She tilted her head to get a better view
Knights would tilt at tournaments to display their skill
The riders tilted fiercely in the medieval reenactment

definitions: cover with a thin layer of tin for protection against rust or corrosion
preserve food in sealed tin cans for long-term storage
examples: They tin copper pots to prevent food from reacting
The factory tins steel sheets for roofing materials
Factories tin vegetables during the harvest season
My grandmother used to tin fruit from her garden

definitions: color something slightly or give it a trace of color mixed with the base
examples: Sunset tinged the clouds with pink and orange
Embarrassment tinged her cheeks with a rosy glow

definitions: experience a slight prickling or stinging sensation in a part of the body
examples: My fingers tingle when they warm up after being cold
Her skin tingled with excitement before the performance

definitions: attempt to repair or improve something in a casual or experimental manner
make small changes or adjustments to something without a definite plan
examples: He loves to tinker with old clocks in his garage
Don't tinker with the settings unless you know what you're doing
She tinkered with the recipe until it tasted perfect
Engineers tinker with the design to improve efficiency

definitions: add a small amount of color to something to change its shade slightly
examples: The hairdresser will tint your hair with golden highlights
Artists often tint their drawings with watercolor washes

definitions: pay or give a tenth part of one's income, especially to support a church
examples: Many church members tithe regularly to support their congregation
Farmers used to tithe their crops to the local parish

definitions: cook or brown food by exposure to radiant heat until crisp
drink to the health or in honor of someone or something by raising glasses
examples: Toast the bread until it turns golden brown
She likes to toast marshmallows over the campfire
Let's toast the bride and groom at their wedding
We toasted his success with champagne

definitions: ride downhill over snow on a toboggan sled for sport or recreation
examples: Children love to toboggan down the snowy hillside
We tobogganed through the forest trail last winter

definitions: switch from one effect, feature, or state to another by pressing a button or key
examples: Toggle between different viewing modes with this button
You can toggle the setting on and off easily

definitions: work extremely hard or incessantly at difficult physical labor over a long period
examples: Farmers toil in the fields from dawn to dusk
She toiled for years to build her small business

definitions: make a short sharp sound with a horn, whistle, or similar instrument
examples: The train tooted its whistle at the crossing
Drivers toot their horns impatiently in traffic jams

definitions: overbalance or cause to overbalance and fall down from an upright position
remove a government or person in authority from power, especially by force
examples: The strong wind toppled several trees in the park
The toddler toppled the tower of blocks
Rebels aimed to topple the dictator from power
The scandal toppled the company's longtime CEO

definitions: set fire to something deliberately, especially a building, as an act of arson
examples: Vandals torched the abandoned warehouse last night
Protesters threatened to torch government buildings

definitions: inflict severe physical or mental suffering on someone deliberately and cruelly
examples: Bullies torment younger students with constant teasing
Guilt tormented him for years after the accident

definitions: attack or sink a ship with a self-propelled underwater explosive weapon
destroy or ruin a plan, project, or possibility of success completely
examples: Enemy submarines torpedoed three cargo ships during the war
The submarine torpedoed the battleship at dawn
One bad review torpedoed the restaurant's reputation
His careless remarks torpedoed the delicate negotiations

definitions: inflict severe pain on someone as punishment or to force them to do or say something
examples: The regime was known to torture political prisoners
Don't torture yourself with guilt over past mistakes

definitions: add up numbers or amounts to find the total sum of items
examples: Tot up the expenses to see how much we spent
The cashier totted the bill quickly on her calculator

definitions: carry something, especially something heavy or cumbersome, by hand from place to place
examples: She totes her laptop to work every single day
Workers tote heavy boxes from trucks to the warehouse

definitions: take part in a tournament or series of contests between knights or competitors
examples: Knights would tourney for honor and prizes
Chess players tourney at the annual championship

definitions: attempt to sell or promote something persistently and often aggressively
sell tickets for an event illegally at inflated prices outside the venue
examples: Companies tout their products through aggressive advertising campaigns
Politicians tout their achievements during election season
Scalpers tout tickets outside the stadium before games
It's illegal to tout tickets at major sporting events

definitions: pull a vehicle or boat along with a rope, chain, or tow bar behind another vehicle
examples: The truck will tow your car to the repair shop
Boats tow water skiers across the lake

definitions: register a symbol, word, or words as a trademark legally to represent a company or product
examples: The company decided to trademark their new logo design
You should trademark your brand name before launching

definitions: travel on a tram or streetcar that runs on rails along public roads
examples: We tram to work every morning in the city
Tourists love to tram around San Francisco

definitions: walk with heavy steps making a loud noise, especially for a long distance
travel from place to place as a vagrant or person without a home
examples: Hikers tramped through the muddy forest trail
Soldiers tramped for miles carrying heavy equipment
He tramped across the country looking for work
Homeless people often tramp from town to town

definitions: put someone into a trance or hypnotic state of altered consciousness
examples: The hypnotist tranced volunteers from the audience
Rhythmic drumming can trance listeners at ceremonies

definitions: conduct or carry out business dealings, negotiations, or exchanges between parties
examples: Banks transact millions of dollars in trades daily
We transact all our business through secure online platforms

definitions: go beyond the normal limits or boundaries of something to surpass or exceed them
examples: Great art transcends cultural and language barriers
Her achievements transcend what anyone thought possible

definitions: put thoughts, speech, or data into written or printed form from another source
write out music or information in another form or system of notation
examples: Court reporters transcribe everything said during trials
Students transcribe lectures to study from notes later
Musicians transcribe songs from recordings to sheet music
Scholars transcribe ancient texts into modern languages

definitions: send or convey something from one place or person to another
pass on a disease or infection to another person or organism
examples: Radio towers transmit signals over long distances
Nerves transmit messages from your brain to muscles
Mosquitoes transmit malaria through their bites
Infected people can transmit the virus to others

definitions: move or transfer something to another place or situation for growth or development
transfer an organ or tissue from one body or body part to another surgically
examples: We transplanted the seedlings to larger pots
The company transplanted its headquarters to another state
Surgeons successfully transplanted a kidney to save her life
Doctors can now transplant hearts with high success rates

definitions: cause two or more things to change places with each other or rearrange their order
write or play music in a different key while maintaining the same intervals
examples: Accidentally transposing numbers can cause serious accounting errors
The editor transposed two paragraphs in the final draft
Can you transpose this song to a lower key?
Musicians often transpose pieces to suit their instruments

definitions: travel across or through an area, especially one that presents difficulties or dangers
examples: Explorers traverse the desert using special vehicles
We must traverse the mountain pass before nightfall

definitions: represent something in a false, absurd, or distorted way that makes a mockery of it
examples: The movie travestied historical events for cheap laughs
Critics said the trial travestied justice

definitions: fish with a trawl net or seine dragged along the sea bottom
search through a large amount of information or area looking for something
examples: Fishing boats trawl these waters for shrimp and fish
Commercial vessels trawl the ocean floor despite environmental concerns
Police trawled through hours of security footage
Researchers trawl the internet for relevant data

definitions: walk on or over something, pressing it down with the feet
walk somewhere carefully or cautiously to avoid danger or offense
examples: Please don't tread on the newly planted grass
Grapes were traditionally tread by foot to make wine
You must tread carefully when discussing sensitive topics
She treads lightly around her temperamental boss

definitions: make or become three times as large or as numerous by increasing threefold
examples: The company hopes to treble its profits next year
Housing prices trebled in just five years

definitions: go on a long difficult journey, especially on foot through challenging terrain
examples: They plan to trek through the Himalayas next summer
We trekked for miles to reach the remote village

definitions: shake involuntarily as a result of anxiety, excitement, cold, or physical weakness
examples: Her hands trembled as she opened the letter
The dog trembled with fear during the thunderstorm
